summary: This is a recorded OIG interview of a Federal Bureau of Prisons Senior Officer at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) regarding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 9-10, 2019. The officer provides details about his shift, the failure to conduct proper counts and rounds, Epstein's lack of a cellmate, and systemic issues at the MCC SHU.

connections.description: Reyes was Epstein's cellmate until he was transferred out of the MCC on the morning of August 9, 2019.
Tartaglione was a previous cellmate of Epstein; there was an incident where Epstein claimed Tartaglione attacked him.
Noel was a correctional officer assigned to the SHU and was responsible for monitoring Epstein among other inmates.

events.title: Epstein's final day and phone call
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was brought back to the SHU from attorney visits around 8:00 PM, given a phone call on a legal line, and later placed back in his cell without a cellmate.

events.title: Discovery of Epstein's death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at the MCC SHU, having hung himself.

events.title: Failure to conduct 4:00 PM count
events.description: The 4:00 PM count in the SHU was not conducted; the count slip was pre-filled using numbers from a locator sheet.

events.title: Inmate Fernandez incident
events.description: Inmate Leonardo Fernandez attempted to grab an unknown item from a visitor, leading to his removal from the SHU and placement on dry cell watch.

events.title: Reyes transferred out
events.description: Inmate Reyes, Epstein's cellmate, was transferred out of the MCC (WAB - With All Belongings) at approximately 8:38 AM, leaving Epstein without a cellmate.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York City
G-tier shower (where Epstein made phone call)
keyFacts: The 4:00 PM count in the SHU on August 9, 2019, was not conducted; the count slip was pre-filled using numbers from an inmate locator sheet.
Epstein was without a cellmate after Reyes was transferred out in the morning; the interviewee claims he notified someone higher up and discussed it with officers Noel and Thomas around 9:30 PM.
Round sheets for the SHU appear to have been pre-filled, as evidenced by consecutive times with minute differences, indicating rounds may not have been conducted as documented.
The interviewee expressed concern about Epstein's demeanor before leaving his shift, telling officers Noel and Thomas to 'watch him' and that Epstein was their priority.
Systemic issues cited include chronic understaffing, overworked employees, lack of clear directives, and the high-profile Epstein being placed in SHU instead of a more secure unit like Ten South.
